node.title: What to Cook This Weekend
node.description: Eric Kimâ€™s new recipe for root-beer ham will deliver incredible results for the holiday.
node.content: ["Good morning. I once spent an afternoon reducing a couple of quarts of Cheerwine, the wildly sweet North Carolina cherry cola, to make a kind of demi-glace I thought I could whip with heavy cream, to anoint pecan tartlets after a Southern-style dinner of grilled lamb, grits and braised root vegetables.", "This did not work, and I was put off cooking with soda pop for a number of years. (I rebounded with this awesome galbijjim that the chef Peter Cho taught me to make, which requires a can of Coke.) Cooking with liquids that contain high-fructose corn syrup is a difficult business.", "But Eric Kim is a remarkable businessman, and his new recipe for root beer ham (above) delivers an incredible result, with the sarsaparilla in the soda imparting a kind of sylvan mintiness to the cured meat. When reduced after cooking the ham, the root beer braising liquid serves as a base for a mustard-rich, syrupy glaze that picks up a high note with a touch of rice vinegar. I suspect he will not be alone in preparing that ham for the holiday season, especially among those who take the time to read his moving essay about developing the recipe in The New York Times Magazine this week.", "Indeed, I might try it this weekend, just as practice, if only so I can follow his suggestion to burble up some stock from the hambone and use it for congee, with a few egg yolks stirred in at the end.", "What else to make this weekend? Cookies, obviously. This awesome black cake from Trinidad\u2019s \u201cNaparima Girls\u2019\u201d high school cookbook. Maybe some maraschino cherries to give as gifts, or to adorn your holiday manhattans.", "I\u2019d enjoy green goddess roasted chicken on Saturday night with oven-fried patatas bravas and braised leeks with Parmesan, perhaps with an apple crisp for dessert.", "And I\u2019d like to assemble Samin Nosrat\u2019s big lasagna for dinner on Sunday, which goes nicely with garlic bread and a Lucali salad. (Would a cannoli cream calzone with honey and orange be overkill for dessert? Not at all.)", "Many thousands more recipes to cook this weekend are waiting for you on New York Times Cooking. (Including this one for baked eggs with onions and cheese!) It is an undeniable fact that you need a subscription to access them. Subscriptions are the fuel in our stoves. They allow us to continue doing this work that we love. If you haven\u2019t done so already, I hope that you will subscribe today. (If you\u2019re looking to knock out some holiday shopping, we\u2019re offering gift subscriptions as well.)", "And we\u2019ll be standing by, just in case anything goes pear-shaped in your kitchen or our code. Drop us a line at cookingcare@nytimes.com and someone will get back to you. (You can also reach out to me, if you\u2019d like to complain or say something kind. I\u2019m at foodeditor@nytimes.com. I read every letter sent.)", "Now, it\u2019s nothing to do with Moxie or Tab, but Sarah Lyall\u2019s Times review of Herv\u00e9 Le Tellier\u2019s \u201cThe Anomaly,\u201d recently translated from French by Adriana Hunter, got me over to the bookstore after work. I\u2019m glad I did that! The novel lies, Sarah wrote, \u201cin that exciting Venn diagram where high entertainment meets serious literature.\u201d", "I\u2019m enjoying the sixth season of \u201cShetland.\u201d", "Here\u2019s Rita Chang-Eppig\u2019s short story, \u201cThe Miracle Girl,\u201d which the Virginia Quarterly Review awarded the Emily Clark Balch prize for fiction, honoring the best work of fiction published by the magazine in a calendar year.", "Finally, Billie Eilish directed and edited the video for her new track, \u201cMale Fantasy.\u201d Watch and listen to that. I\u2019ll see you on Sunday."]
